item.description: Pretty good bento boxing place. A little pricey but no need to tip.

item.title: Nakazawa
item.description: It’s an Omakase. Michelin 1 star. Very good for the price. Got sake pairing + sushi + EXTRAS… only $220 per person. The lychee sorbet was awesome.

item.title: Shuko
item.description: Really good. Got the kaiseki ($175), and they gave a lot of sushi pieces. The dessert, rhubarb sorbet, was really good.

item.title: Shabu Tatsu
item.description: Fairly inexpensive, but not very OG. Portions are small, and no where as good as LA shabu shabu.

item.title: Robataya Ny
item.description:
This place was such a gimmick. Very showy like Benihanas but way worse. Food was just ok and super pricey. They have bday celebrations… super weird.

But it’s CLOSED.

item.title: Kosaka
item.description: Pretty good kaiseki (~$180).

item.title: Mew Men
item.description: Japanese lunch was cheap and good. But this place is CLOSED now replaced by Menkoi Sato, a ramen place.

item.title: Abiko Curry
item.description: Abiko Curry is a Japanese curry restaurant that I had visited before in Koreatown way back in September of 2018. We were near the neighborhood, and I thought to check it out again. I remembered the curry and flavors being one of my favorite Japanese curry places in the city, but I also remembered that the “medium spicy” level was uncomfortably intense. This time around, I want to give it another try to see if I can get a better feel for it.

item.title: Curry Ya
item.description: The spicy pork tonkatsu was pretty good. One of the better Japanese curry places in the city.

item.title: Uma Temakeria
item.description:
Terrible “sushi burrito”

This place is CLOSED for obvious reasons.

item.title: Go Go Curry
item.description: Good lunch spot and fast. Cheap.

item.title: Okonomi
item.description: Really good Japanese breakfast place.

item.title: The Sosta
item.description: This place was ok. Pasta was good, but it needs protein. The meat cheese board was just ok.

item.title: Lilia Caffe
item.description: Had to make reservations 30 days ahead of time. Food was decent. Interior is nice. Homemade pasta. Good date place. Slightly overrated. Very similar to Culver City Bucato (before it shuttered) a few years ago.

item.title: I Sodi
item.description: Food was just ok even though it’s highly recommended by people. Probably a good date place though.

item.title: Lasagna Ristorante
item.description: Lots of food for lunch and just ok.

item.title: Gran Sasso
item.description: Really good. Homemade pasta, and steak was good. Wasn’t that expensive either. Has been renamed to Scriptum Brooklyn. Not sure if it’s the same place.

item.title: Grazie
item.description: I only ate here because it was close to the MET. I don’t remember what I had, but I’ve only written that it was good.

item.title: Dirty Bird to Go
item.description: This place sucks compared to KFC/Popeyes. Yeah I said it.

item.title: Fuku
item.description:
A few doors down from the Ssam bar, this place is pretty good. $12 for a combo which was basically drink, fries, and the sandwich. The Momofuku red sauce is always good.

Unfortunately this is CLOSED.

item.title: Emmy Squared
item.description:
Summary

I’ve been here numerous times to both the East Village and Manhattan locations, and they have consistently delivered pretty well within expectations.

The fried chicken sandwich is delectable. It was really good and pretty spicy with the right kick.

The Le Big Matt is like pretty big too. The cheese is super melty which makes it a little messy but pretty delicious.

The Roni Supreme is by far my favorite. It’s exactly what the description says. Be warned, it’s a little on the salty side.

item.title: Westville
item.description:
This fried chicken sandwich was a special served during lunch and was quite good.

I think Westville’s normal menu seems bland and isn’t that great.

item.title: Rider
item.description: Was actually really good, and was one of the first places I went to when I moved here.

item.title: St Tropez
item.description: Great for the price, although I was here on a pescetarian date. I thought I could do pescetarian, and I can’t. Would come back for actual meats.

item.title: Cherche Midi
item.description:
Same owner as the Minetta Tavern. Great for the price. I liked teh suckling pork because it was straight up fat with crispy skin. Got the whole fish, and it was great too.

Only problem is it is CLOSED.

item.title: Le Relais De Venise L'entrecote
item.description: This review is for the Midtown East location of Le Relais De Venise L’entrecote. The previous review I had was for the closed SOHO location, which I was complaining that they charged $5.50 for tap water back in 2018. Fast forward about 3 years later post pandemic, how does this location fare compared to the previous one? I will say much better. Note that this location did not appear to charge for tap water.

item.title: Le Singe Vert
item.description: Pretty good. Decent price. Don’t have much else to say I guess.

item.title: Le Coucou
item.description: Amazing place. The baked alaska and veal tongue were really good. It’s also not too expensive.

item.title: Le Coq Rico
item.description:
Specializes in French style chicken. $100 for a whole chicken. Chicken was soft and juicy with that wild flavor. Pretty expensive for what it is, but it was good.

Probably would be OK with Costco chicken over this.

item.title: Excuse My French
item.description: This was pretty good. Definitely would come back here again when craving for duck rillettes and other charcuteries.

item.title: La Maison Du Croque Monsieur
item.description: The croque monsieur was mediocre at best.

item.title: Raclette
item.description: They are super stingy with the cheese, and it stinks the instant you walk in. But otherwise, it’s delicious. You are allotted 2 cheese shavings. One of the guests at my table did not want their second shaving, so I used their second shaving for a total of three shaving. It’s good but not too expensive.

item.title: Grom
item.description: I like the gelato here. A bit expensive but good.

item.title: Grace Street
item.description:
Desserts are pretty good, but I don’t get why there is always a line here.

The milk tea was just ok.

The donuts were good.

item.title: Dominique Ansel Kitchen
item.description:
Interesting desserts and pretty good. In the summer, they have burrata frozen yogurt as well as some type of watermelon frosty thing.

They’re also known for the Cronut, but it can be bought at the Spring location.

item.title: Patisserie Chanson Dessert Bar
item.description: Amazingly good albeit super expensive for a dessert tasting menu. Six courses plus wine pairing for $150+. Geez.

item.title: Soft Swerve
item.description: Pretty good matcha soft serve ($5).

item.title: Daly Pie
item.description: Got the rhubarb, and it was pretty good. I love them rhubarb pies.

item.title: Ample Hills Creamery
item.description: Got the pistachio brittle, and it was mediocre. I think Van Leeuwen is better.

item.title: ChaTime
item.description: Passion fruit green tea was just OK.

item.title: Kulu Desserts
item.description: It’s ok. Lots of durian stuff. Black sesame wasn’t that great.

item.title: Creperie
item.description: Really good and BIG.

item.title: Spot Dessert Bar
item.description: Pretty good. Some interesting stuff, but maybe somewhat gimmicky?

item.title: Kreuther Chocolate
item.description: Across from Bryant Park. Expensive AF chocolate ($3 pp), but the other desserts were amazing. Really good chocolate though.

item.title: Viva La Crepe
item.description: Crepes were whatever. Why?

item.title: Prince Tea House
item.description:
Good crepes and milk tea. The decor is interesting here.

The iced passionfruit green tea was a nice drink for the hot summer weather.

The takoyaki was pretty good.

item.title: Maison Kayser
item.description: The Christmas log is good. A lot of Frenchy desserts.

item.title: Cafe Zaiya
item.description: Decent black sesame bubble milk tea with red bean dessert bakery stuff.

item.title: Patisserie Tomoko
item.description:
They have dessert tasting menus. The black sesame is good.

The black sesame ice cream is amazing. Not too sweet, but also very punchy in flavor. Delicious.

The green tea roll was very good. The center was cold and creamy, but not too sweet.

The pumpkin tart was really good too. The crust was flaky similar to an egg tart.

item.title: Clever Blend
item.description: Bagel was pretty bad. The toasted coconut cold brew wasn’t that good.

item.title: Birch Coffee
item.description: The cold brew was pretty good, and the Ethiopian beans were good too.

item.title: Prodigy Coffee
item.description: This was just OK. Still prefer Toby’s cold brew.

item.title: Tobys Estate
item.description: This is pretty good. The Brooklyn Blend beans are good for cold brew and hot.

item.title: Gimme Coffee
item.description: It’s ok. Beans are not as good as Toby’s. It’s closed though.

item.title: Brooklyn Ball Factory
item.description: Decent place.

item.title: Mountain Province
item.description: I like their latte.

item.title: Happy Stony Noodle
item.description: Cheap. It’s ok beef noodle + stinky tofu. Beef noodle with mustard green was ok.

item.title: Noodle King of Nyc
item.description: Decent noodles. Cheap. Tastes kind of homely.

item.title: Hot Box
item.description: Decent personalized hotpot place. Similar to Boiling Point.

item.title: Ho Foods
item.description: Taiwanese beef noodle was pretty good. $$$ but the broth was good. Long wait, but not sure if it’s worth it. I kinda want to make my own again.

item.title: Joes Shanghai
item.description: Was good and cheap, but not like amazing. LA XLBs still better.

item.title: Just for Fen
item.description: Was decent albeit expensive. Didn’t care for the noodles at all.

item.title: Dim Sum Go Go
item.description: This place is very bleh for dim sum. I was the only Asian diner.

item.title: 99 Favor Taste
item.description:
Summary

This place is ok for hotpot and bbq. Keep in mind this is a All You Can Eat restaurant. There are a decent amount of choices for the hot pot meats/veggies as well as the BBQ meats. Downstairs they have tables with a grill and individual hot pots. The tables are huge even though there is always a line now unless you eat off hours. For 2 people, we decided to skip waiting for our own and share a table with other people. Those other people never came, so we basically had the big table to ourselves.

item.title: Yuan
item.description:
Noodles pretty good, but service sucks big time.

It’s probably why this place is PERMA CLOSED.

item.title: Shorty Tang
item.description: So so for lunch. Cash only. The sesame noodles was just ok.

item.title: New May Wah 359
item.description:
Taiwanese food. Rice cakes good. Everything else eh. Cash only.

This place is PERMA closed.

item.title: Sunshine
item.description:
Dim sum is ok. Less wait than Jing Fong. Chicken feeet not as good as LA.

This is PERMA closed.

item.title: Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao
item.description:
Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao is one of those XLB restaurants that is not often brought up in the XLB fights because it’s not that accessible. The original location is in Flushing, so it’s a bit far from Manhattan. Many people do end up going to Joe’s Shanghai to get their fix, but fortunately now a Manhattan location of this restaurant has opened in Koreatown.

I had originally gone to the Flushing location and said the following:

item.title: Dumpling Man
item.description: XLB was just ok. Price was cheap.

item.title: Yaso Tangbao
item.description: This place was pretty good for the price. The soup dumplings had the authentice black vinegar sauce with ginger. They were open on Thanksgiving.

item.title: M Noodle Shop
item.description: Terrible but cheap Chinese. The pork chop on top of rice was terrible.

item.title: Vanessas Dumpling House
item.description: Pretty good. Pass on the beef noodle though.

item.title: Mimi Cheng's Dumplings
item.description: Expensive for what it is.

item.title: Pearls
item.description: Caribbean “pita” pocket stuff is pretty good. The chips with guac and shrimp +1.

item.title: Baroness Bar
item.description: Pretty good albeit expensive. The beer selection here is pretty good.

item.title: Burger Garage
item.description: Reminds me of Pops but more standard burgers. Still pretty good and not too pricey.

item.title: Juanchi
item.description: Pretty good burger if your’e in the area.

item.title: The Spotted Pig
item.description: Burger was OK. Very bleu cheesy. The shoestring fries were annoying to eat and overly salty.

item.title: Chumleys
item.description: Their burger is better than Minetta’s. Nuff said.

item.title: Burger & Barrel
item.description: Got their special $68 white truffle burger. Was good, but not worth it. Don’t spend $68 for white truffles when they’ve practically lose their scent on the plane over here.

item.title: Minetta Tavern
item.description: This is the infamous Minetta Tavern. I had been here back in mid 2010s, and it was pretty good. Before I met my partner, I used to come here once every few months to just scarf their Black Label burger. The price for this was just barely over $20. Now in recent times post-pandemic, it’s been a bit more difficult to walk in without reservations. We were able to sit at the bar on a Friday late-afternoon around 4:55 PM without reservations.

item.title: 5 Napkin Burger
item.description: Overrated. I don’t get why people think this is good. Rather go to Shake Shack or something else.

item.title: Creamline
item.description: Pretty good. I like both the fried chicken and cheeseburger. Probably wouldn’t go here again if it’s out of my way.

item.title: Momofuku Nishi
item.description:
This is suppose to be Italian, but I ate here before they rebranded. They had the Impossible burger here, and it was surprisingly decent.

The red sauce is really good with the fries.

item.title: Buns Bar
item.description: Greasy, but good and filling. I skip the sliders and went straight for the regular burger.

item.title: Bareburger
item.description: Decent gourmet burger. I probably never crave this when I want a burger.

item.title: Mister Dips
item.description:
This place was pretty good. It’s in that Vale hotel.

The waffle fries were good as well as the soft serve.

item.title: Pops
item.description:
One of the best fast-foody burger places in Brooklyn. Cheap, quality, and delish. Cholo is where it’s at. They use Pat La Frieda meats for their burgers, and it’s not too expensive.

Too bad it’s PERMA closed due to rent increase. In place of it is a sex shop.

item.title: Blue Collar
item.description: This place is worse than Pops. Too bad Pops closed down.

item.title: Jack's Wife Freda
item.description:
Got the Shakshooka. I also asked for hot sauce, and it was some wet guacamole green looking thing. It has a nice kick to it. The shakshooka was also green too instead of the normal red sauce. Has a good kick to it and was also more sour than usual. Also got a side of the duck bacon which was interesting.

Again, skip the lines and sit at the bar.

item.title: Moe's Doughs Donut Shop
item.description: So apparently, the head baker from Peter Pans down the street now works here. Regardless, the ECLAIR with the white filling in the middle is really really good. It’s not too sweet and CHEAP @ $1.50. Better than DKs. Skip the cake donuts of course.

item.title: House of Small Wonder
item.description:
This place is cash-only and has Japanese style breakfasts. Think tomato sauce on top of an omelette that has fried rice in it.

I got the hamburger steak of course. Decent. Decor is interesting.

item.title: Sunday in Brooklyn
item.description:
The Korean looking sammich was good, and so was the biscuits and gravy. Can you tell I’m a biscuits and gravy kinda person?

If there’s a line outside, check the bar inside. Might be able to walk in and sit there instead of waiting for a table.

item.title: Buvette
item.description: This place is really good. Their steamed eggs are super fluffy, but pretty expensive. It’s crowded but easy to walk in as 1.

item.title: Egg Shop
item.description: This place sucks, is pricey, and is extremely overrated. I don’t understand why this place has so many people. $18 for a egg on top of salad with fried chicken.

item.title: Russ & Daughters Cafe
item.description: This place was pretty good, but I feel it’s overrated. It has a lot of lox stuff. I didn’t care much for it, but then again I don’t care about lox either.

item.title: Le Barricou
item.description: Came here for brunch. Got the duck hash, and it was pretty good. Service was slower than a snail crawling across the sidewalk.

item.title: Jimmy's Diner
item.description: Their biscuits and gravy with eggs was surprisingly good. Cheap but cash only.

item.title: Reunion
item.description: Their shakshooka is really good! Coffee is good too but definitely get the shakshooka if eating.

item.title: Egg
item.description: I liked it. A little pricey but good stuff.

item.title: John Brown Smokehouse
item.description: For whatever reason, the brisket was dry even though it’s recommended by Yelpers. The pastrami was also dry and overly salty. Generally the BBQ was bad. Maybe it was just this one time, not sure.

item.title: Hometown BBQ
item.description:
Summary

Been here a few times already now. It’s always a trek to get here. It’s about a mile away from the Smith G stop subway station. If you go walking at night, it’s a little sketchy at times.

The wait for the food on a prime time Saturday night can be up to an hour if the line starts near the band. If you want to avoid the line, come here circle 11 AM on a Sunday.

item.title: Daisy May's Bbq
item.description:
Terrible BBQ. Go here for cheap stale dry meats in tourist hell.

Oh apparently it’s permanently closed.

item.title: Fette Sau
item.description: BBQ is really good. Better than Mighty Quinn’s.

item.title: Mighty Quinn's BBQ
item.description: Their brisket is always good for the price.

item.title: Spritzenhaus 33
item.description: Crowded AF. Really noisy, bartenders slow AF. Standard Biergarten is better as well as the other one in Billsburg.

item.title: Hotel Delmano
item.description: Cool place. They have food. Not too expensive. Right next to the water sorta in Williamsburg.

item.title: Due West
item.description: Great bar/vibe. This new-ish place is definitely going to be popular.

item.title: The Ragtrader and Bo Beep Cocktail
item.description: Interesting bar. Bar upstairs is cool. Piano bar downstairs is really KEWL.

item.title: The Otheroom
item.description: Good date vibe in the West Village.

item.title: Elsa
item.description: Cool vibe. Good place to take people who live in Carroll Gardens area circa Smith St.

item.title: Dutch Kills
item.description: Decent vibey bar similar to some LES places, but way out in Queens. But who knows maybe Long Island City might be the next spot after Williamsburg!

item.title: Public Hotel
item.description:
People come here to drink because they’re retarded. Terrible drinks. College-ish atmosphere. Pretentious for no reason.

Oh, it has the orange escalator hallway that everyone likes to take pictures of. There’s also that purple glass window back that people like too.

item.title: Dear Irving
item.description: Good old boys bar. Think jazzy-ish. Nice place.

item.title: Fresh Kills
item.description: Decent stop for a drink before going elsewhere.

item.title: Post Office
item.description:
Cool place for whiskeys.

But it’s CLOSED.

item.title: Attaboy
item.description: You tell them what ingredients you like in your drink, and they make something magical for you.

item.title: Golden Years
item.description: Fried chicken sandwich was ok. Has a kick to it just like every fried chicken sandwich place. Cash only though. Don’t think I’d care to come back.

item.title: Troost
item.description: Cool divey spot. Cheap drinks. Lots of gin/tequila based cocktails. They occasionally have random small bands.

item.title: The Spotted Owl Tavern
item.description: Ok spot.

item.title: Mother of Pearl
item.description: Interesting decor. They have a shark drink where it has a bunch of blood on it. Notice a bunch of people bring their dates here.

item.title: Mayahuel
item.description: Was a Mezcal speak easy place when I went. Decent mezcal based cocktails. It had a change of ownership recently.

item.title: Copper and Oak
item.description: This place is cool. All scotches and nice ambiance.

item.title: Standard Biergarten
item.description: Vibe reminds me of Wurstkuche in Los Angeles. But without the distinct dogs and beers. Still cool though.

item.title: Employees Only
item.description: It’s alright. Bar gets crowded. Food is decent. It’s a has been.

item.title: Raines Law Room
item.description: Cool place. It’s in some random building basement, and the couches are comfy. Feels a little noir-ish.

item.title: Bathtub Gin
item.description: Went here with a friend for the first time. Saw a random bouncer looking guy standing outside of a coffee shop. There’s a door next to the coffee shop that leads into an apartment complex. My friend and I looked at each other. We were thinking we were suppose to open this door, and that this “speak easy” is somewhere in this apartment complex. We tried to open the door, but it wouldn’t turn at all. We stood there with a confused look in our faces as we check the address again. The random bouncer guy asked, “Are you guys looking for the bar?”

item.title: The Tippler
item.description: Cool place beneath Chelsea Market.

item.title: Barn Joo
item.description: I had been here several years ago, and it hasn’t changed much at all. This is a Korean bar type restaurant in Union Square with a myriad of different Korean foods including noodles, rice, buns, etc. The last time I was here, I had ordered a bunch of side dishes and had wrote down typical Korean American bar food. This time around, we decided to try out Korean BBQ. The staff led us up the stairs where there were many tables with BBQ grills in them.

item.title: Peter Luger
item.description: Peter Luger’s steak house has been around for a very long time. At one point, it even had a Michelin Star. Many tourists always recommend eating here and rave about it. The locals though on the other hand are rather indifferent. People have told me that their steaks suck and that their best dishes are their appetizers. Others have told me it’s the best steak they ever had. Does it really live up to the hype? Time to find out.

item.title: Momofuku Noodle Bar
item.description: Like Ippudo, this was supposedly another must-try ramen place that was highly raved by the NYC food scene. I got to this spot right when they opened, and there was already a small line outside in this frigid cold weather. Inside, they have counter top seating for 1-2 people as well as a some picnic table setups for larger parties. There was no David Chang spotted here, but how was the food?

item.title: Forge
item.description:
Formerly known as “Marc Forgione”, this restaurant has moved from its prior Tribeca location to a different Tribeca location. Since then, they have lost their Michelin Star, but it is still a staple restaurant for those familiar with the history of this restaurant. It was quite easy to make reservations a few days in advance.

When I first came here in 2012, I wrote:

Marc Forgione is one of the Iron Chefs on Iron Chef America. This is his first restaurant, and at the time of this writing it has 1 Michelin Star. Like Michael Voltaggio, this restaurant is one of his babies, so he periodically is cooking in the kitchen to make sure everything comes out as he desires. Unfortunately he didn’t cook today, but I just want to preface this by saying this is definitely one of my favorite restaurants ever that I’ve tried so far.

item.title: WD~50
item.description: I first found out about WD~50 from my friend who wanted to try it out for the longest time. On research, I found out one of the Bravo’s Top Chef previous contestant owns this restaurant. His name is Wylie Dufresne. He is well known for pushing a movement towards molecular gastronomy, which is basically a different way to cook things. This 1 Michelin Star restaurant’s menu is pretty sparse in choices in that you basically choose from 2 different types of tasting menus, the cheaper or the more expensive. Optionally, you could order 2 items off any of the tasting menus at the bar for $25. We of course opted for the expensive one considering we have no plans on coming back any time soon.

item.title: Momofuku Ssam
item.description: One of my goals was to knock out some popular Momofuku establishments. SSAM was one of them. The SSAM Bar is on the San Pellegrino world’s 50 best restaurants list at the time of this writing. The service style is basically family style, so there are a lot of sharing plates. Portions are small for large groups probably, but decent sized for small groups 2-4. The decor has a very modern feel to it.

item.title: Barrio Chino
item.description: This is a very small restaurant in the lower east side, so be prepared to share tables if necessary. In my blog of NYC eats, I totally forgot to blog about this one. This place is supposedly known for their spicy margaritas. My party each ordered habanero margaritas, and they were delectable. They were spicy with a kick, but not overbearing. For many, habaneros are already daunting. But once you soak the habanero into the tequila, it’s really not that bad in terms of spicy.

item.title: Rice to Riches
item.description: This will be my last NY food post for a while. For the last day to cap off the trip, we went to Rice To Riches in Nolita. This was actually really close to our Blue Ribbon meal a few posts ago. Rice To Riches is basically the equivalent to Baskin Robbins 31 flavors in LA. Instead of many choices of ice cream, you have many choices for tapioca. You also have the option of sampling any flavor that you want. I’m not a huge tapioca person, but I was willing to give this a try

item.title: Lombardi's
item.description: Since 1905, Lombardi has been credited with developing New York style pizza and being the first pizzeria in the United States. This has been challenged by many NYC locals especially pizza aficionados. Having been here back in 2012, I’ve had the pleasure of witnessing the evolution of this pizzeria. I’ve been here several times, and it’s always easier to walk in early dinner times vs prime time. You’ll be seated fast and food will come right away especially now there are so many other competing pizza places nearby.

item.title: Shake Shack
item.description: I only got a few more NYC eateries to blog about then I’ll be done for now. Shake Shack is basically the west coast’s equivalent to In-N-Out. The one we visited was the original Shake Shack that sits in the middle of some sort of park near Eleven Madison. For a rather chilly day, there was still a long line of people that took approximately 30 minutes for us to get our food. We had time to kill, so why not?

item.title: Katz's Delicatessen
item.description: Here in Los Angeles, we have a ton of pastrami places. My favorite meat is in fact pastrami. Not only do I enjoy the saltiness flavor in the cured meat, but I also enjoy how tender the meat is. I’ve been to Johnny’s in Culver City, Canter’s Deli near West Hollywood, Jerry’s Famous Deli, Langer’s in Los Angeles, etc. Compared to all those places, I very much prefer Kat’z Deli. The meat is chunky, soft, and super flavorful.

item.title: Chikalicious
item.description: Per recommendations for dessert after dinner at Momofuku Ko, we visited Chikalicious. All I know is this place is busy normally with lines outside the door. My buddy and I visited it on a Thursday night, and to our surprise it wasn’t overly busy at all. In fact we got there right at 9:30 PM. There were 2 seats at the counter right in front of the Chef Chika. Yes, Chika is her name. She’s shy and quiet yet is very friendly. I’m not a dessert person in general, so it should take something really good to wow me.

item.title: Bacaro
item.description: I have a ton of food porn pics that I haven’t put online yet, but I’ll get through it. If you don’t know already, I went to New York City this past February and tried out some of the local hot spots. This is my first time to the east coast, so I really didn’t care for any of the touristy places. My buddy and I, per recommendation, went to Bacaro which is Italian inspired cuisine. My plane had just landed about an hour and a half ago, and this is the first place that we went to.

item.title: Luke's Lobster
item.description: I had a pleasure of visiting Luke’s Lobster in East Village when I traveled to NYC from Los Angeles. What you see here is the “Taste of Main” sample platter. It consists of: half lobster sandwich, half shrimp sandwich, half crab sandwich, 2 crab claws, 1 bag of chips, and 1 bottle of pop. The only comparison I have for this is The Lobsta Truck here in Los Angeles. For those that don’t know, it basically is a food truck that serves lobster sandwiches that are pretty small.

item.title: Doughnut Plant
item.description: Doughnut Plant is one of those institutionalized donut places in New York City. Between Dough and this place, it’s really difficult to go wrong, and each person will have their own preference. I remember what was unique about this donut place was mainly their flavors as it was unique and different. The size of the donuts are not as big as Dough, but they are almost as puffy and airy.
